title: Centrally stored credentials not accepted for Linux (SSH)
author: MisterDeeds
body_snippet:
We use the function of the credentials stored in options. This works without any problems for Windows. Under linux, the user name is inserted correctly, but the password is not accepted and must be entered separately each time.

## Expected Behavior
For Linux (SSH) connections, the credentials stored in Options should be used to automatically log in to the shell.

## Current Behavior
The user name is inserted correctly in the shell, but the password is not accepted and must be entered manu...

comments.author: simonai1254
comments.snippet:
How does it behave when adding the credential to username / password field in the connection properties (your first screenshot)? 
Using this I never had issues with version up to 1.77.2-nb. 

And please keep in mind, that with 1.77.3-nb changed settings are not saved properly as writing to file is disabled for development reasons. Not sure how it actually behaves, but it might be part of the problem.

comments.author: MisterDeeds
comments.snippet:
Dear Simon

Thank you for your feedback. 

If the credentials is entered directly in the connection, it works perfectly.

We store the connection data in an SQL database not in a file. With an RDP connection, for example, the login works without any problems.

Currently @Kvarkas seems to be trying to implement profile based login settings, which I guess makes this bugfix obsolete (though needs to be considered for the new implementation if relying on legacy code).
